awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Design and Provisioning for Inter-Datacenter Multigranular Flexible Optical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
There is an ever-increasing demand for cloud computing services, and large-scale datacenters are constantly evolving to meet this demand. As the need for data and data analytics grows, providers are turning to geo-distributed datacenters to provide customers very low latency access to information and computational capability. This results in high capacity, highly-varying inter-datacenter network traffic that must be reliably and cost-effectively accommodated by fiber optic networks.  Recent advances in agile and flexible optical networking have made Flexible Optical Networks (FONs) a promising candidate for meeting these dynamic and heterogeneous connection demands. The goal of this project is to develop network design and provisioning strategies for inter-datacenter FONs that can support a wide range of data traffic flow. To address the continued exponential growth in network capacity, the project includes consideration of a novel, flexible, cost-effective optical technology,  which introduces a way of bundling large traffic demands together as they get routed through the network.  The results of the project will inject leading-edge research into education, and enable more efficient and cost-effective distribution of information between datacenters.

The research project addresses challenging problems in the design and operation of multigranular flexible optical networks. The challenges demand the development of new strategies to maximize the utilization of precious network resources. Novel algorithms for network design and resource provisioning will be developed, and will be accompanied by sophisticated mathematical models and bound analysis for performance quantification. The specific research objectives of this project are to: 
1. Explore the multigranular FONs design space and evaluate performance and complexity trade-offs, balancing performance against complexity or cost.
2. Design algorithms for provisioning bandwidth requests in multigranular FONs.
3. Design scalable and flexible algorithms on provisioning virtual network (VN) requests by jointly allocating compute and communication resources in inter-datacenter networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the last several years, large-scale datacenters built using commodity servers and network equipment have enabled distributed data processing and storage, and several cloud services. As the scale of the data continues to increase, cloud service providers and datacenter network operators are increasingly leaning towards geodistributed datacenters. Inter-datacenter traffic is growing at a faster rate due to factors such as VM migration, data replication, and data relocation following disasters. The size of data that can be processed in a reasonable amount of time is not only determined by the available processing capability but also by the bandwidth and latency of the interconnecting network. These new requirements pose a serious challenge on network operators who have to come up with a flexible and reliable solution, while considering the operational benefits that can potentially result. Recent advances in agile and flexible optical networking have made Flexible Optical Networks (FONs) a promising candidate for meeting the dynamic and heterogeneous connection demands between datacenters.

This project successfully proposed novel and effective approaches for route selection, spectrum management, modulation format assignment, and core/fiber allocation for heterogeneous bandwidth requests by taking the network topology and expected traffic pattern into account. Physical layer impairments and spectrum fragmentation were also considered. The project also investigated the virtual networks embedding problem. Each virtual node in a request is mapped to a single physical node, with sufficient available computing resources. Each virtual link is mapped to a physical path, and a band of contiguous frequency slots is allocated to the virtual link based on its bit rate requirement. Both offline and online versions were studied. The allocation of multi-laser sliceable bandwidth variable transponders (SBVT) was also considered. The requests included both delay-sensitive requests (resources are allocated when the request arrives) and delay-tolerant requests (requests can be scheduled at a future time as long as the required resources can be allocated before a specified deadline).

We used the following methods for evaluating the performance of the proposed methods: (a) Integer Linear Programming (ILP) optimization, (b) simulations, and (c) probabilistic modeling. The developed algorithms were also compared with state-of-the-art benchmark algorithms from the literature.

The results of the project were published in journals and peer-reviewed conferences, and were presented in Student Project Symposiums at San Jose State University (SJSU). By developing design and provisioning strategies for multigranular inter-datacenter networks, the project will advance the state of the knowledge in the field of optical networking. Large-scale data centers are continuing to evolve and grow to meet the increasing demand for cloud-computing services. As data volumes grow and latencies become more important, distributed data centers demand high-bandwidth connectivity among them. As optical networking is the only viable technology for such bandwidths, this project will also benefit data center networking, and by extension, the larger digital society.
